column45: Improve the professional services and training accessibility by reviewing cost and frequency.
column116: Challenges: 1.	Lack of training opportunities _ with our initial engage/purchase, we also coordinated formal training courses for 10-15 resources.  We were able to spread the cost across multiple groups and arrange the training in locations where travel wasnÍt necessary.  Now that we only need training for 1-2 resources at a time, there is no formal online or local training options for these resources.  That needs to be addressed formally.  AMEX is being allowing us to join an internal CA training course but this is a one off opportunity and we need more options domestically and for our offshore resources.  Additionally, there are no advanced levels training options.    2.	CA primarily they have 1 deployment model.  They align their effort with a single delivery project.  CA tends to provide virtualization or automation services that support that project and then look to move to another individual project.  They donÍt focus on how to provide a complete solution at a platform level.  CA needs to think through how to deliver on a larger scale.  3.	Professional services support is very expensive.  Onshore/onsite support is $265/hr and offshore support is $88/hr.  We have been offered long term (12 months guaranteed) rates of $60/hr for offshore.  No reduction has been provide for onshore.  Until we have built our resident employee team knowledge, these prices hinder our ability to fully utilize the capabilities of the tool.  Accolades:   1.	Our assigned sales rep and account manager have been incredible partners.      2.	I commend CA for arranging to have the large AMEX turnout at CA world.  For many of the teams that havenÍt been exposed to the tool, it was very beneficial and gave them an additional forum to engage CA and their other customers.

column45: Answering for the company is difficult. In general, the company is well intentioned and has good products.  Let me offer a breakdown of Good/bad/ugly: Good - Your security product stack is strong and competes / beats many of your competitors. It is open and not locked on particular technologies which allows me certain flexibilities. Bad - Your security products team is not customer focused and speaks only management speak. They lack an understanding of the industry they serve and fail to integrate into our business. Your sale to us occurred exclusively due to the Account Management team and our knowledge of the potential of the products. The product team nearly lost the sale due to their inability to understand our need and apply the proper products. Ugly - The services side for security operates only under a rigid waterfall methodology. This does not meet our business need and caused large headaches. This should be revamped and we should be reimbursed for all services charges from CA due to lost time.  More Good - the LISA product set is very easy to use and always works as advertised. It integrates well and we will likely be purchasing enterprise licenses soon. Bad - The services expense is to high for this product. Selling based on "value" is not applicable. Likely your company's administration costs are too high and you should trim so that CA does not become a bloated enterprise unable to move quickly and service customers. Ugly - The contracts team lost larger sales of this product due to the inability to move on west coast hours. We were held up a number of times by "lawyers in NY" as the team put it.

Then once the problem was reproduced, I received the following update weekly for 5 months   "Engineering is continuing to investigate this issue.  I do not have an  update from them at this time. column116: Currently I have been tasked to replace our current enterprise monitoring environment with CA Spectrum Infrastructure Manager and CA Service Operations Manager. We are going on 18 months and we are not even close to being finished with this implementation. When we made the move to go forward with both of these products we purchased sixth months of managed services to help us implement these products. We basically spent six months setting up the products and troubleshooting connectors. We barely completed 20% of the original task list we had for the managed services offering. We have asked for additional training in advanced event management in SIM only to find out there is not any training available and managed services is the route we need to go down to to complete the necessary projhect tasks.   Another frustration is that these products were sold to help alleviate administration time (as we are resource contrained) and has been anything but. In our current environment we have 8 rules to handle a set of events and in CA SIM, according to CA support, it would take 6000 event rules to do the same thing.  We posed the question to a managed services rep, and it was oh we can do something similiar in a managed services offering.   My company should not have to spend additional money to get your products to work if you provided the education needed to make them work. We should not have to spend money on managed services every time we need to do something a little outside the traditional SNMP event.

column116: My comments stem from a particular long running integration issues with our Siteminder configuration, using an add-on from the CA Labs. We suffered two  serious outages of a high profile high value service here at Barclays. Support services consistently cited an Oracle product, and the configuration (which in turn was configured by CA - some time ago) as being the root cause. Despite the efforts of our Account team it appeared to be impossible to engage correctly with both the CA support and the CA Labs. Although the labs attempted to reproduce the issue our input or for the requirements of the test were ignored or lost. My team invested a lot of time in testing and as a result we were able to clearly articulate the technical root cause of our issue. Which we stated at the SM Addon, 'LCL', appearing not to scale up to support large scale users. With this new understanding we have engaged with services and are currently working on strategic solutions. column45: It has to do with obscure technical capabilities of the eHealth product. Although I appreciate the 'certified' MTF files, having our own compiler makes a lot of sense as vendors introduce new products and we may need obscure, vendor specific features provided by their MIBs that the CA Certified MTF does not support. For example, the ability to dump the content addressable memory (CAM) entries of a switch. Having our own MIB compiler to exploit these features would be a powerful addition.
column75: Be more open with the engineering interfaces so we can exploit them for our unique environment. column116: We need more technical content and not have to play '20 questions' about the engineering aspects of eHealth. column116: Point of clarification on my answer to the ease of use for the CA Products. I answered it at only slightly above mid because it is not easy to use a robust product like CA Clarity PPM but that is to be expected from an integrated application suite that supports so many IT Management Processes.  With that said, I will reiterate my suggestion that CA should offer a lighter subscribe-and-go Saas based version of Clarity to enable smaller less mature user groups to leverage the product immediately. This would allow them to gain the immediate benefits of a basic (light) PPM solution and would increase the likelyhood that they will turn to the more robust version when they have matured their PPM practices. Obviously ensureing the ease of data migration from the basic (light) version to the enterprise version would be a great selling point as well.

column116: Overall I feel the products are very functional.  I do have a few gripe points:  1.  It does seem that the QA process for new releases is weak in comparison to other companies (CA PAM 4.0/4.1).    2. Upgrading to new versions takes much longer than I would prefer.  Our last Service Desk upgrade took 13 months.  While some of this is internal politics, a good portion was form customization, bug fixes, patching, showstoppers and support fixes, and learning curve.  3. It takes much longer to resolve support issues than we'd prefer.  We currently have a support case that has been open for >1 year!  4. Support does not even look at contact preferences.  I have my contact preference set to email because my time is highly booked.  This being said, Every time support has contacted me in the last 6 months there has been a phone call prior to an email.  This is unacceptable.  I have informed support at least 3 times in the last year to email me and if a conference call is needed we can schedule a time.  Even after all this communication, I still get phone calls before emails.  Why even bother asking communication preference if support is not going to honor the preference???

column59: During the deployment, numerous functionality gaps (such as smart card not meeting federal PKI standards and Kerberos authentication failed redirects not working) and product bugs were identified. Utilization of stricter quality assurance testing and validation for future releases would avoid delays in implementations and upgrades.  Documentation could also be improved/updated to be more relevant. Such as Kerberos, which did not state that the UPN had to match, as well as the SPN. This was found through trying different configurations and testing; eventually going away from the product documented configuration to make a more stable / highly available configuration using the VIP names.  The product itself does provide many benefits however. It is still too early to fully explore the security enhancements available, such as the 12.52 enhanced session assurance, but looking at the overall capabilities documented there's a lot of room to provide a more secure WAM solution for our client with this product.   On the professional services side, a lot of time was wasted on what appeared to be fairly small tasks - such as configuring Kerberos. During the demo period of 1 week all the authentication schemes were functioning, at a basic level, within that time frame. After the procurement and into the actual DEV configuration it took months to get a very basic setup. The team was unable to utilize consultants very efficiently due to the time spent just reading documentation and troubleshooting through trial/error.  As the implementation and migration of current applications proceeds, the score I would give would of course change based on issues/benefits seen. At this time a '6' is all I can give it due to the numerous problems and delays due to product bugs/gaps or lack of experience of the professional services. The latter, services, being a large factor is lowering the overall score.

column116: We have historically had negative experiences with Clarity upgrade attempts. With the current upgrade, our account rep said he would withold our access to / discussions with CA technical resources unless we agreed to listen to and participate in a discussion related to increasing our footprint of the Clarity product. Then, when we finally had discussions with CA tech resources and posed reasonable questions that weren't answered in CA upgrade documentation, it was suggested that we should hire CA professional services to assist with the upgrade. The Clarity upgrade documentation from CA is incomplete, and does not provide a clear path of getting from one version of the product and version of Windows OS to the next version of the product and Windows OS. The CA support associate advised that this is a known issue, the info is not in the upgrade documentation, and our best bet is to read user forums and blogs. We are still struggling thru the upgrade, and hopefully we will succeed at some point without having to bring in CA consultants for $250 an hour.

column59: The main item from a monitoring perspective is addressing functionality concerns within the product. The ability to schedule blackouts and to apply intelligent ticket routing should be part of of the user interface.  Database Monitoring has been a sore spot for us since signing the ELA in 2009. We have been unable to move the ball forward in this area due to a lack of confidence (both internally and with our customer) with Insight. The issue has been the amount of intervention by the different teams to setup monitoring on 1 DB Instance. The description by a CA Senior Technician of the tool being a "bear" to implement is an excellent description.  We have not received good feedback of Nimsoft's ability to accomplish DB Monitoring as an alternative.
column75: Again, the lack of monitoring functionality compared to other vendors has made it tough to increase our CA Monitoring Footprint at Acxiom.
column116: I personally apperciate and like most of the CA associates who work with the Acxiom Monitoring Team. I find them to genuinely care about developing a strategic partnership with Acxiom Monitoring.  The issue I have is we've been unable to consistently move the ball forward with the CA Monitoring products over the past 5 years due to unaddressed functionality concerns. These include scheduling blackouts via FE GUI, lack of a multi-ticket routing strategy, complexity in regards to rolling out DB Monitoring for a single DB Instance, lack of a monitoring solution for Unix File System Monitoring, and eHealth is not being HA solution.  We currently monitor over 20k devices within my Business Unit. From a management standpoint, we are able to accomplish a considerable amount more with less with the team using the BMC Monitoring Products (Patrol and TM-ART) vs the team using the CA Monitoring Products.   BMC Monitoring Tools = 600:1 (device to 1 monitoring associate) CA Monitoring Tools = 1200:1 (device to 1 monitoring associate)  These ratios have been consistent over the past 4 years.

column59: Our relationship got off to a rough start when we did not receive everything that was proposed in the solution.  CA did rectify this by providing the additional module that was required.  However, there is still some discovery of what was really included in their proposed solution vs. what is available at an additional cost.   Another area of concern is in the professional services.  The technical support for sales seemed to really understand the product, our requirements, and our implementation plan.  However, the support provided for our implementation did not have near the technical expertise.  While our implementation provided ample opportunity for learning the product, we were needing a much deeper knowledge of the product and the issues we were dealing with from our professional services.  We eventually found that using the product support provided for the best technical capabilities but really impacted our schedule.
column75: Meet commitments and requirements.  Thus far, it has been difficult to understand where we are with functionality that we were promised in the proposal.  Hopefully with the NDA in place, we will be able to better understand schedules and path forward on critical functionality.  Finally, good documentation is key for a solution provider.  To date, we have found the documentation to be lacking.  Often times it refers to examples that don't exist or does not contain enough detail for admins to use.  Basic installations should not require support from Product Support when good documentation is provided.
column116: Right now, our biggest impediment is lack of concise documentation.  We have struggled with the installation of the Secure Proxy Server due to the lack of good documentation.  Things that should be relatively simple are very time consuming as we have to enter service requests to get questions answered and examples provided.

Better understanding of regulatory controls and how they will impact the way Financial institutions manage the Vendor relationship going forward. The OCC and MAS have both brought in new guidelines and this seems to have caught CA on the back foot. Considerable time and effort was made by SCB to bring CA up to speed with those new guidelines and the impact they will have to the way that CA do business. with FI's in the future.
column116: I always saw CA as been innovators in helping organisations mange complex problems in a very uncomplicated way. My experience of dealing with CA over these past 6 months, is they are unaware of the implications of some of the decisions they were making. The new OCC and MAS guidelines are a fundamental gamechanger in the way that FI's treat the IT Vendors they use - and all of this seemed to be news to CA. We have still not been able to close out some of the contractural issues that as an FI we are mandated to implement, and CA are either saying this can't be done or give timelines that are not acceptable to the regulator. I don't feel that as a customer we should be explaining legislation to our Vendors, rather if they took our business seriously they should be coming to us with the solution already prepared. I can only stress these are my own personal views, in dealing with CA.

column45: CA has a diverse product suite that can be used to meet nearly any business relevant demand; however the technology SME support can be thin.    Additionally there have been times when closing a deal CA has worked to create an artificial sense of urgency related to contracts and pricing, and have used high pressure sales tactics.  My organizationÍs leadership is not a great fan of how CA does business, which makes my job that much more difficult when working through my organizationÍs processes to implement CA tools and technologies.   I caution my peers when they are looking at CA products that CAÍs business model has evolved from an acquisition / bleed the maintenance e stream dry to one of close the deal quickly by crisis management.  CAÍs key acquisitions of best of breed technologies make engagement with these business practices worth it.  However, as technologies move forward I would urge caution on this practice.
column75: My account team seems to be in a continuous state of flux.  The sales team that I would have described as ñtrusted advisor / strategic partnerî left CA immediately after negotiating a large 3 year contract negotiation with my organization.  Those actions speak volumes as to CAÍs reward and retention system of key customer facing staff.  Trust is earned through consistent actions over time. This cannot take place with a sales team that is continually in flux.  Technical support of outstanding issues is a big problem for my account.  My organization wrings the value out of our tools, and due to this I feel that I am using my production environment to beta test CA products.  When we contact CA support we get passed from agent to agent, with long lag times when our tickets are moved off-shore.  CA removed a key role for my account who managed our tickets internally, and I had to apply pressure to CA to reinstate that role.  During the time that we had no advocate, minimal progress on our issues was made.  Now, some progress is being made, however I still see a lack of a sense of urgency on the part of CA support related to my organizationÍs outstanding items.  My latest escalation related to technical support to my sales team to date has not been answeredare they an advocate?  Are my concerns being addressed?  I donÍt know, and I donÍt think it is my place to chase the individuals who are supposed to be my strategic partners to get answers to questions that a simple e-mail response would resolve.  Finally, there has been more than one occasion when our sales engineering team has provided me data that I have used to procure solutions internally and externally, then after the fact the data has been communicated to be incorrect, necessitating additional purchases on my end.  This is highly difficult for me to remediate with my organizationÍs procurement and budgetary constraints.

column116: It is unrealistic to expect that the team members selling and supporting our account remain the same, but relationships that are built over time are a key component on how your company is perceived by your customers. When the shift changes, newer faces have expectations from previous accounts and may not "fit" in with the new culture. That appears to have happened here. While we retain a key member of the account team, several newer members have been introduced with mixed results. Personalities are a key success factor when it comes to delivery of an $8-20M sale. Right now, the account team seems to have forgotten who is selling and who is buying. While it would be very painful to disengage from the CA product suite, that option is being considered. I cannot forecast what will happen over the course of these contract renewal negotiations, but if we are to establish a harmonious resolution of our current differences, a realignment of attitude would certainly help.

column100: We have used AutoSys since 1995 and have always liked it and thought of it as an exceptional product, requiring little maintenance.  However, since upgrading to the r11* release and WCC, it has become very complex, requires more overhead particularly because of the 'agents' and requires far too many patches to maintain.
column116: They need to understand we cannot apply patches at the drop of a hat.  Patching require outages that impact the users and the business.  We have to 'package' the vendor scripts in a tool to be pushed out to hundreds of agents for all OS types for each environment -- which requires testing and troubleshooting the packaging.  This is all very time consuming.  We are also required to follow our Change Management process, testing in the lower environments first, before eventually progressing to our production envirionment.  Due to segregation of duties for SOX requirements, we must engage multiple teams to apply the patches, making it resource intensive.  Any time we encounter an issue with a patch, we must communicate the issue to management and all users and business areas and provide regular updates for the root cause and estimated time until resolution.  The more issues we encounter, the more resistent management becomes about applying the patches in production because we cannot afford production outages.

column75: Spend whatever resources required to make all apps fully functional for us.  We have purchased a large amount of your tools and we've never been able to realize the full benefit.  Some of these issues may be internal to our organization, but my group has limited influence to try and convince people of that and push things forward.  If we had a CA engineer onsite (few days to a week, or however long it takes) to represent us, speak as the expert, and help drive the issues, it might lend credibility to our case and help us prompt the needed action.  We have had the tools for nearly 3 years and we've never had everything fully integrated and functioning 100%.  You guys have been "super" great about providing resources for short-term engagements -- more health check, configuration assistance and training sessions, which are very much appreciated and provide added value for us.  But what we really need is someone who can stick around long enough to get familiar enough with things to understand where the problems lie, identify root cause, and help us remediate the issues to get the tools fully functional.

column59: Improve quality before shipping product - fewer bugs.  In particular, make sure a fix to one problem doesn't cause other even worse problems. column108: This box is too small but I'll try to summarize: There is a chicken-and-egg problem here.  To get what I want from CA I think I'd have to participate directly in an agile sort of iterative development process.  This would help ensure requirements are accurately solicited and documented, followed by verification that the delivered product fulfilled requirements.  However, I am reluctant to offer more of my time than CA already gets from me because my observation is that however much CA may wish to be such a wonderful partner (itself a dubious proposition -- it seems more that CA is far more devoted to creating the perception than the reality of "indispensable business partner") I am doubtful based on four years' experience with the company that it will ever be able to deliver this experience.
column116: Stop trying to be everything to everybody; you end up making obvious ploys to cement vendor locking which produces mediocre results and breeds resentment from your captive customers. column16: Director of Project and Delivery Management
column45: I love the tool, but it really could be easier to do business with CA. A few things come to mind:  1. Give me a local rep. Right now, I have a sales rep that is across the country because of a former affiliation with a parent company (which we've recently split from). So what happens is that I miss local gatherings because my salesperson is unaware of them. I'm in Tennessee and he's in Minnesota. I can understand if we were still part of the parent company, but we're not anymore and despite my requests for a local rep, I am still assigned to the same rep in MN.    2. Setting up new users for Business Objects is really tough. Love the capability that this reporting tool gives me, but getting the apps installed, then getting access to the VPN is just time-consuming and toug (we're an on-demand customer). It should be simpler to build custom reports from data that's in Clarity without jumping through these hoops.    3. Recently, I found out that hardware transactions can't be 'consumed' in Clarity without either importing them into the transaction list or by integration directly with the ERP. A recent trip from the Sales rep and a pre-sales support informed me that we could XOG in transactions, but it would require development from the offshore team to build a spreadsheet for us to XOG the data in with. It feels like this is something that probably already exists, but I'm being asked to pay an additional $8k to develop that spreadsheet. Shouldn't this be simpler?
column75: Provide more best practices guidelines. For a while, you were putting out "Green Books" on how best to accomplish some things with the Clarity tool but I haven't seen one in awhile. We have used the Green Book on the MSP / Clarity integration and are about to use the one for security setup. I really wish there was one for financial management because that's where the real value of the tool lies. The online help is not valuable when you're trying to figure out how to configure the tool properly or fix an improper setup for better/smoother use. The guides seem to fill the gap between the tactical "how-to" from online help and the strategic "how-to" necessary for good streamlined use of the tool.
column100: We use it for tracking all our projects, time-tracking, financial management and forecasting, and change control. We are beginning to use it for program and portfolio management and believe the tool could be more useful if we knew more best practices for how we setup and use the tool. I love the financial management of the tool (except the reporting for it) and love that we can build workflow directly in the tool. We need more training on it to be more successful and I'm hoping to take advantage of the training offered next year.
column116: We're probably one of your smaller customers and for the last 3 years, I've felt like I was on an island. Several years ago (2007 time frame), I heard from a Clarity rep at least once per quarter. Now I'm lucky if I hear from someone at CA who cares about my account even once per year. CA always seems anxious for me to sign a 3-year contract, but then I don't hear from anyone too often outside of contract renewal period. Please act more interested in my implementation of the product, even if it's just a quarterly hour-long call to point me to the support information contents that might help me find answers. I end up spending so much time Googling to find answers in the CA Community because the search engine on the CA support site doesn't usually return any useful results. I just need to feel like I'm not in this alone.

column75: These are from my personal perspective only --  1)  Provide more things as part of the systems that we currently have, rather than as separate applications that need to be purchased (ie: Service Catalog, Process Automation etc) 2)  Provide a service as part of the support offering to assist with patches and upgrades, with regards to merging the patched or upgraded forms with the customer's adapted forms.   3)  Before offering new functionality to customers (such as mobile access), ensure that it can be adapted to function the same way that their system functions (required fields, custom fields etc). 4)  Provide more user-friendly administration, support, troubleshooting and customization processes --- drag and drop interfaces, easier creation of custom fields etc. 5) Provide more user-friendly and less technical ways to implement, administer and use additional applications such as Process Automation.   6)  Offer more discounted pricing on things (such as additional licenses, or additional applications) for companies that already own many CA products and systems.   7)  Provide customers on a regular basis with a better vision of where the systems and products are heading, what new functionality will be in store with future upgrades, including a cohesive focus on how various systems can work together.  (and not just posting something on your website that we have to try to find)
column116: It's my opinion that companies like to see a vendor that offers additional services at no charge, and more discounts on licenses or additional products -- especially those companies that own several CA products.    Companies also like to feel that their unique needs can be met in a system without causing additional work to be required when patches or upgrades are needed.  I was surprised with the SDM product that there wasn't an easier, non-technical way to seamlessly merge the form adaptations that were made during the implementation phase when doing patches and upgrades.  This makes a company reliant on the vendor to assist with certain patches and all upgrades, unless they have a dedicated technical expert on staff -- which I would think most companies wouldn't have or want to need.    I believe that most companies are looking for less technical and more user-friendly administration, support, troubleshooting, customization and maintenance of all applications.

column116: O projeto de implantaÜo da suÕte CA adquirida pela DATAPREV _, segundo o Gartner, o maior caso mundial tanto no quesito de complexidade quanto de quantidade de produtos. Dentre os produtos CA sendo implantados simultaneamente estÜo: CA Spectrum, CA eHealth, CA NetQos, CA Virtual Assurance for Infrastructure Managers, CA Application Performance Manager, CA Capacity Manager, CA Service Desk Manager, CA Configuration Automation, CA IT Client Manager, CA User Activity Reporting Module, CA Business Service Insight, CA Workload Automation DE, CA ArcServe RHA e CA EEM. Um projeto deste porte necessita de acompanhamento mais prÑximo por parte da CA para auxiliar a DATAPREV a transformar esse caso de aquisiÜo em um sucesso. Entendemos que o passo inicial para viabilizar esse acompanhamento seria a realizaÜo de assessment pela CA, sem custos para a DATAPREV, sobre o nÕvel de utilizaÜo de seus produtos apontando aÝes para otimizar os resultados da empresa com o apoio de ferramentas CA e para planejar uso de horas de consultoria contratadas junto ö empresa parceira da CA que venceu a licitaÜo em 2012.
column117: "The project of implementing the CA suite acquired by DATAPREV is , according to Gartner , the world's largest event both in the issue of complexity as the number of products. Among the CA products are being deployed simultaneously : CA Spectrum , CA eHealth , CA NetQoS , CA Virtual Assurance for Infrastructure Managers , CA Application Performance Manager , CA Capacity Manager , CA Service Desk Manager , CA Configuration Automation , CA IT Client Manager , CA User Activity Reporting Module, CA Business Service Insight , CA Workload Automation DE, CA ARCserve RHA and CA EEM . A project of this size requires close monitoring by the CA to help DATAPREV to turn this case into a successful acquisition . We understand that the initial step to enable such monitoring would be to conduct assessment by CA, at no cost to DATAPREV , on the level of use of their products pointing actions to optimize business results with the support of CA tools to plan and use consulting hours contracted with the partner company CA who won the bid in 2012 ."

column45: It's a use versus support question. From a functionality standpoint, the tool is very good. I would recommend it from that perspective. From a support standpoint, it has been challenging at best. Part of the challenge we've had has been trying to install NFA/CAPC onto State Farm supported servers. The installs assume an "out of the box" config. But, as a large enterprise, we tend to lock everything down tight and loosen functionality as needed. This has manifested many challenging issues along the way. There have been two support analysts that have been completely awesome (Justin and Chris). If I only worked with them, I'd probably rate this as a 9-10. Unfortunately, that's not realistic. The other folks I've worked with have tried to be helpful. But, if the answer was not in the knowledge base, they were stumped. They'd defer to the development team. But, in most cases, it would take multiple days for them to respond - leaving the support analyst in a lurch as the middle man. If the support analysts had the ability to troubleshoot more on their side (like Justin and Chris have in the past), that would definitely improve the rating. Likewise, if turnaround time from the dev team was more timely, that would help too.
column75: Improve support.

column116: Our current account team is flexible and innovative.  They attempt to understand our challenges and tailor services to meet those needs.  A welcome change from previous CA account management of years past.  Initial acquisition of products is but a small part of the picture.  Ongoing support and enhancement in the form of DAR enhancements is important to allowing customers, especially conversion customers, to continue to meet the needs of those they serve.  Currently the DAR process provides little or no feedback regarding acceptance and product roadmap inclusion.  This process needs to change to provide short cycle acceptance or rejection and intended release inclusion.  Waiting several months to even know if an enhancement is going to be included in the product development cycle is getting to be less and less tolerable.  Conversion customers wish to provide equivalent or better capabilities based on the replacement.  These DAR requests often address gaps hindering easy adoption and conversion for the new tools.   The support center does do a very nice job answering questions regarding product usage and break/fix situations.  They involve whomever they need to answer our questions.  Please continue to recognize and reward that organization.

column59: Who uses this product in production?  I feel like I am wearing a straight jacket when it comes to the dashboards in displaying what I need.  The panels are very restricting in the combination of metrics that can be displayed together.  I should be able to create a simple dashboard with a panel that has three columns, device, cpu utilization, memory that will display ALL devices (NOT JUST Top N.  Currently I can only get a panel with device and cpu and another with device and memory.  I can only get them in Top N.  Now I have two panels that will display different devices on each row instead of a one to one list.)  Some metrics obviously have buggy graphs that are displayed in a panel, i.e. a utilization metric should not show a bar that appears 100% utilized.  A total storage size metric should not even show a bar graph at all since it will always appear 100% which is easily confused at quick glance.  Because dashboards are horrible, I cannot get what I need for reports.  Without the flexibility in reporting, this product is useless.
column75: CA products are good at getting data in, (though even that can be difficult at times as it requires so many different products to do a simple task or costs six figures all the time to get a "add-on" in order to get the data for the feature the product claims to have. (Yes the product can monitor virtual environments.  Oh, what, we didn't tell you when you purchased the product that to do that you will need to spend another six figures in order to use that feature?!?  We're sorry, but yeah you will have to spend more.)  Oh and you will probably (most likely) need to purchase professional services to configure that feature because its quite involved and if not done right will not work for you. (translate: our product manuals are lacking and the product is not intuitive nor does it configure right half the time.) Wake up, smell the coffee, its 2014 and there are better programming technologies available now for a much better user interface and experience.  CA's products are stuck in the stone age.  Single pane of glass is seriously lacking for UI navigation and configuration.  Every time I add another CA product I feel like we need to add another FTE or two just to administer and configure it on a daily basis.  Instead of the focus being on the customer, the focus with CA products is concerned with reliability of the tool and getting out of it useful information to proactively resolve issues before the customer calls. CA products I have come to realize do not provide any compelling value to keep them around.  They cost more than they save.  When that is realized, its time to research other products and there have been some great ones to choose from these days.  They may not be at the top of the Gartner quadrant or have certain "patents" touted but they are making inroads and moving in the right direction in the quadrant.  Plus the other products will get us what we need with less hassle and expense. I realized a year ago that being at the top of the quadrant does not make a vendor tool the best choice and that I need to look at those who rate lower, but are making consistent progress improving.  Those are the ones who have something higher to aim for and are focused on doing so.
column99: Spectrum eHealth IM/CAPC APM VAIM SDM
column108: All need better UI experience. Configurations need GUI. Too much configuration, too many individual pieces (always have to purchase something else to make a feature work), foot prints are too big for the performance provided, really there are too many problems to list and the turn around time is too slow and most will be ignored.  I'm not sure why I filled this survey out.
column116: We are a heavy Microsoft shop when it comes to our server infrastructure and private cloud.  I will be looking at other options such as SCOM 2012 to monitor our infrastructure since we own it as part of our Microsoft contract.  There is a lot of open support available on the Internet, plenty of resources if needed for little to no cost. Monitoring our virtual environment is critical these days and I can do it for far less investment than with CA.  In order to do that with Spectrum and hence with IM/CAPC I would need to invest in the VAIM add-on for SystemEDGE to monitor virtual at an astronomical cost.  I MUST monitor my Hyper-V environment, there is no choice if I am to understand my environment.     Spectrum for us is a pain in the manage going forward.  We built a private cloud, our intent is to have all virtual servers using dynamic addresses because it makes sense in a cloud.  But Spectrum cannot monitor a device by hostname, it can only monitor by IP.  So that means every time an IP changes, someone in the NOC has to research the alert and if its changed they must update each device manually.  Not practical today nor as business grows.  Oh I understand that if I buy the virtual add-on, its suppose to keep up with that for me (though that is questionable given we are on a Hyper-V environment and CA's commitment in that area is lacking on what can be measured and detected in Hyper-V.) I can see that the move at CA is towards Nimsoft Monitor and looks like a promising prioduct, but again that does not help me as I cannot monitor virtual unless I purchase a probe for that at a ridiculous cost.  I have two virtual environments to monitor; 1) two 64 node/each data centers, 2) a 32 host Citrix environment running on Hyper-V.  Do the math. Nevermind the endless problems configuring features that turn out to be buggy...

column99: CAMM - when purchased we needed SONET reporting functionality in the product. It was requested in June 2013 and was promised for March 2014. Now in mid-June 2014 we are close to having it working but still bugs being resolved. CA Support has been quite weak at everything related to this product. We were under the impression that this was a packaged product. It is very obvious that this is a custom solution rather than a shrink wrapped product. This has caused a lot of grief in that CA Support cannot help us. The product did not initially install properly in May 2013. CA Support assisted through a WebEx however made numerous undocumented changes to our production environment. It eventually resolved the problem but now we could not reinstall the production environment from scratch due to the missing undocumented steps used to make it work. Recently when we psuhed hard enough we had determined that CA Support does not have a lab environment and needed to use our lab to "try" some things to add the missing SONNET functionality that had been promised for March 2014.
column108: CA should come clean with potential customers on what is an off the shelf product vs a customer built application.
